Matthew Barzun, US ambassador to the United Kingdom (Picture: Rex)

Anyone listening to Desert Island Discs today will have heard more than just how great Prince’s song Delirious is.

US Ambassador Matthew Barzun, today’s guest, also discussed the reality of trade post-Brexit.

He said that President Obama had been right to warn in April that Britain would go ‘to the back of the queue’ when it comes to negotiating trade deals.

Before voting for Brexit, the UK was at the front as it was part of the EU which is currently hammering out a major deal with the USA known as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, or TTIP.

But now we have effectively given up our place in the line, he said.

Obama warned Brexit could hurt trade (Picture: Saul Loeb/Pool via Bloomberg)

‘If you step out of the front of the queue, by definition you are no longer at the front and some notion that you can jump further ahead; you just want to say that is not the trend for the types of big deals we are doing these days,’ he said.

House of Cards creator doesn’t think UK politics is worthy of comparison to show But the ‘special relationship’ between the two countries would remain, he said.

‘I think we did what best friends do. So before the referendum when we were asked – and President Obama said it probably most forcibly – of course, it’s up to you but if you ask us, we will tell you what we think which was we value a strong UK in a strong EU.’

The interview was recorded after the referendum results and broadcast today.

However, others have claimed trade prospects with the US are looking hopeful, citing a bill calling for a new trade deal proposed by Republican politicians.

title: Britain ‘WILL be at the back of the queue for trade deals with US after Brexit’
